desk, seen from the back, looks at a series of A.I.-generated images of Black women on two computer monitors." class="css-rq4mmj" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/07/05/multimedia/03ai-bias8-wjvc/03ai-bias8-wjvc-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale" (min-width: 1005px) 60vw, 100vw" decoding="async" width="600" height="400"/></picture></div><figcaption class="css-1ifeaca e1maroi60"><span aria-hidden="false" class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Stephanie Dinkins at work in her Brooklyn studio. For the past seven years, she has experimented with A.I.’s ability to realistically depict Black women smiling and crying. </span><span class="css-1u46b97 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Flo Ngala for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-103l8m3"><div class="css-1u5onbp epjyd6m1"><div class="css-165eim7 ey68jwv0" aria-hidden="true"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/zachary-small" class="css-uwwqev"><img alt="Zachary Small" title="Zachary Small" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/05/01/reader-center/author-zachary-small/author-zachary-small-thumbLarge.png" class="css-dc6zx6 ey68jwv2"/></a></div><div class="css-233int epjyd6m0"><p class="css-4anu6l e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">By </span><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemProp="name"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/zachary-small" class="css-n8ff4n e1jsehar0">Zachary Small</a></span></p></div></div></div><div data-testid="reading-time-module"><div class="css-3xqm5e"><time class="css-1g7pp1u e16638kd0" dateTime="2023-07-04T11:50:34-04:00">July 4, 2023</time></div></div></header><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The artist Stephanie Dinkins has long been a pioneer in combining art and technology in her Brooklyn-based practice. In May she was awarded $100,000 by the <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.guggenheim.org/video/artist-profile-stephanie-dinkins" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Guggenheim Museum</a> for her groundbreaking innovations, including an ongoing series of interviews with Bina48, a humanoid robot.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">For the past seven years, she has experimented with A.I.’s ability to realistically depict Black women, smiling and crying, using a variety of word prompts. The first results were lackluster if not alarming: Her algorithm produced a pink-shaded humanoid shrouded by a black cloak.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“I expected something with a little more semblance of Black womanhood,” she said. And although the technology has improved since her first experiments, Dinkins found herself using runaround terms in the text prompts to help the A.I. image generators achieve her desired image, “to give the machine a chance to give me what I wanted.” But whether she uses the term “African American woman” or “Black woman,” machine distortions that mangle facial features and hair textures occur at high rates.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Improvements obscure some of the deeper questions we should be asking about discrimination,” Dinkins said. The artist, who is Black, added, “The biases are embedded deep in these systems, so it becomes ingrained and automatic. If I’m working within a system that uses algorithmic ecosystems, then I want that system to know who Black people are in nuanced ways, so that we can feel better supported.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">She is not alone in asking tough questions about the troubling relationship between A.I. and race. Many Black artists are finding evidence of racial bias in artificial intelligence, both in the large data sets that teach machines how to generate images and in the underlying programs that run the algorithms. In some cases, A.I. technologies seem to ignore or distort artists’ text prompts, affecting how Black people are depicted in images, and in others, they seem to stereotype or censor Black history and culture.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Discussion of racial bias within artificial intelligence has surged in recent years, with studies showing that <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/09/technology/facial-recognition-race-artificial-intelligence.html" title="">facial recognition technologies</a> and digital assistants have trouble identifying the images and <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/23/technology/speech-recognition-bias-apple-amazon-google.html" title="">speech</a> patterns of nonwhite people. The studies raised broader questions of fairness and bias.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Major companies behind A.I. image generators — including OpenAI, Stability AI and Midjourney — have pledged to improve their tools. “Bias is an important, industrywide problem,” Alex Beck, a spokeswoman for OpenAI, said in an email interview, adding that the company is continuously trying “to improve performance, reduce bias and mitigate harmful outputs.” She declined to say how many employees were working on racial bias, or how much money the company had allocated toward the problem.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-d754w4 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:270.6666666666667px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-gbc9ki ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="false" class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">An example of the distortion Dinkins found using a prompt of “A Black woman crying”’ in 2016 using the platform Runway ML.</span><span class="css-1u46b97 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">via Stephanie Dinkins</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-d754w4 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:164.9777777777778px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-gbc9ki ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="false" class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Some of the distortions from images of “Black woman smiling” in 2020.</span><span class="css-1u46b97 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">via Stephanie Dinkins</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Black people are accustomed to being unseen,” the Senegalese artist <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://lindarebeiz.com/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Linda Dounia Rebeiz</a> wrote in an introduction to her exhibition “In/Visible,” for <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://feralfile.com/exhibitions" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Feral File</a>, an NFT marketplace. “When we are seen, we are accustomed to being misrepresented.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">To prove her point during an interview with a reporter, Rebeiz, 28, asked OpenAI’s image generator, <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://openai.com/dall-e-2" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">DALL-E 2,</a> to imagine buildings in her hometown, Dakar. The algorithm produced arid desert landscapes and ruined buildings that Rebeiz said were nothing like the coastal homes in the Senegalese capital.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“It’s demoralizing,” Rebeiz said. “The algorithm skews toward a cultural image of Africa that the West has created. It defaults to the worst stereotypes that already exist on the internet.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Last year, OpenAI <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://openai.com/blog/reducing-bias-and-improving-safety-in-dall-e-2" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">said</a> it was establishing new techniques to diversify the images produced by DALL-E 2, so that the tool “generates images of people that more accurately reflect the diversity of the world’s population.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">An artist featured in Rebeiz’s exhibition, <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.instagram.com/minneatairu/?hl=en" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Minne Atairu</a> is a Ph.D. candidate at Columbia University’s Teachers College who planned to use image generators with young students of color in the South Bronx. But she now worries “that might cause students to generate offensive images,” Atairu explained.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-d754w4 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:217.82222222222222px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-gbc9ki ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="false" class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Minne Atairu, an artist and educator, at the Armory in 2022 with works based on a data set of Black models found in vintage Black magazines.</span><span class="css-1u46b97 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">via Minne Atairu</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Included in the Feral File exhibition are images from her “Blonde Braids Studies,” which explore the limitations of Midjourney’s algorithm to produce images of Black women with natural blond hair. When the artist asked for an image of Black identical twins with blond hair, the program instead produced a sibling with lighter skin.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“That tells us where the algorithm is pooling images from,” Atairu said. “It’s not necessarily pulling from a corpus of Black people, but one geared toward white people.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">She said she worried that young Black children might attempt to generate images of themselves and see children whose skin was lightened. Atairu recalled some of her earlier experiments with Midjourney before recent updates improved its abilities. “It would generate images that were like blackface,” she said. “You would see a nose, but it wasn’t a human’s nose. It looked like a dog’s nose.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In response to a request for comment, David Holz, Midjourney’s founder, said in an email, “If someone finds an issue with our systems, we ask them to please send us specific examples so we can investigate.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Stability AI, which provides image generator services, said it planned on collaborating with the A.I. industry to improve bias evaluation techniques with a greater diversity of countries and cultures. Bias, the A.I. company said, is caused by “overrepresentation” in its general data sets, though it did not specify if overrepresentation of white people was the issue here.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-d754w4 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-gbc9ki ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="false" class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Minne Atairu’s “Blonde Braids Study IV,” explores the limitations of Midjourney’s algorithm to produce images of Black women with blond hair. One experiment produced a twin with lighter skin instead. “It’s not necessarily pulling from a corpus of Black people, but one geared toward white people.”</span><span class="css-1u46b97 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">via Minne Atairu</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Earlier this month, Bloomberg <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2023-generative-ai-bias/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">analyzed</a> more than 5,000 images generated by Stability AI, and found that its program amplified stereotypes about race and gender, typically depicting people with lighter skin tones as holding high-paying jobs while subjects with darker skin tones were labeled “dishwasher” and “housekeeper.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">These problems have not stopped a frenzy of investments in the tech industry. A recent rosy report by the consulting firm McKinsey <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/06/14/technology/generative-ai-global-economy.html" title="">predicted</a> that generative A.I. would add $4.4 trillion to the global economy annually. Last year, nearly 3,200 start-ups received $52.1 billion in funding, <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.globaldata.com/media/business-fundamentals/artificial-intelligence-startups-raise-over-50-billion-venture-capital-funding-in-2022-reveals-globaldata/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">according</a> to the GlobalData Deals Database.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Technology companies have struggled against charges of bias in portrayals of dark skin from the early days of color photography in the 1950s, when companies like Kodak used <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.npr.org/sections/codeswitch/2014/04/16/303721251/light-and-dark-the-racial-biases-that-remain-in-photography" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">white models</a> in their color development. Eight years ago, Google disabled its A.I. program’s ability to let people search for <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/05/22/technology/ai-photo-labels-google-apple.html" title="">gorillas and monkeys</a> through its Photos app because the algorithm was incorrectly sorting Black people into those categories. As recently as May of this year, the issue still had not been fixed. Two former employees who worked on the technology <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/05/22/technology/ai-photo-labels-google-apple.html" title="">told The New York Times</a> that Google had not trained the A.I. system with enough images of Black people.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-of9q2l e73j0it0"><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz- css-13wylk3 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:386.6666666666667px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-fpbvhh ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="false" class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">This reporter’s experiments with DALL-E 2 and the prompt “Black woman smiling” produced facial distortions.</span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz- css-13wylk3 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:386.6666666666667px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-fpbvhh ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="false" class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Example of facial distortion on DALL-E 2 program to the prompt “Black woman smiling,” including a five o’clock shadow.</span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Other experts who study artificial intelligence said that bias goes deeper than data sets, referring to the early development of this technology in the 1960s.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“The issue is more complicated than data bias,” said James E. Dobson, a cultural historian at Dartmouth College and the author of a recent book on the <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.upress.umn.edu/book-division/books/the-birth-of-computer-vision" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">birth of computer vision</a>. There was very little discussion about race during the early days of machine learning, according to his research, and most scientists working on the technology were white men.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“It’s hard to separate today’s algorithms from that history, because engineers are building on those prior versions,” Dobson said.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">To decrease the appearance of racial bias and hateful images, some companies have banned certain words from text prompts that users submit to generators, like “slave” and “fascist.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">But Dobson said that companies hoping for a simple solution, like censoring the kind of prompts that users can submit, were avoiding the more fundamental issues of bias in the underlying technology.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“It’s a worrying time as these algorithms become more complicated. And when you see garbage coming out, you have to wonder what kind of garbage process is still sitting there inside the model,” the professor added.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0"><a class="css-yywogo" href="https://auriea.art/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Auriea Harvey</a>, an artist included in the Whitney Museum’s recent <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://whitney.org/exhibitions/refigured" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">exhibition</a> “Refiguring,” about digital identities, bumped into these bans for a recent project using Midjourney. “I wanted to question the database on what it knew about slave ships,” she said. “I received a message saying that Midjourney would suspend my account if I continued.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-d754w4 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-gbc9ki ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="false" class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Stephanie Dinkins, inaugural recipient of the LG Guggenheim Award for technology-based art, in her studio in Brooklyn. She says she is not giving up on technology despite problems.</span><span class="css-1u46b97 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Flo Ngala for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Dinkins ran into similar problems with NFTs that she created and sold showing how okra was brought to North America by enslaved people and settlers. She was censored when she tried to use a generative program, <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://replicate.com/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Replicate</a>, to make pictures of slave ships. She eventually learned to outwit the censors by using the term “pirate ship.” The image she received was an approximation of what she wanted, but it also raised troubling questions for the artist.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“What is this technology doing to history?” Dinkins asked. “You can see that someone is trying to correct for bias, yet at the same time that erases a piece of history. I find those erasures as dangerous as any bias, because we are just going to forget how we got here.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Naomi Beckwith, chief curator at the Guggenheim Museum, credited Dinkins’s nuanced approach to issues of representation and technology as one reason the artist received the museum’s first Art & Technology award.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Stephanie has become part of a tradition of artists and cultural workers that poke holes in these overarching and totalizing theories about how things work,” Beckwith said. The curator added that her own initial paranoia about A.I. programs replacing human creativity was greatly reduced when she realized these algorithms knew virtually nothing about Black culture.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">But Dinkins is not quite ready to give up on the technology. She continues to employ it for her artistic projects — with skepticism. “Once the system can generate a really high-fidelity image of a Black woman crying or smiling, can we rest?”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div></div></div></section><div class="bottom-of-article"><div class="css-ddxw8g"></div><div class="css-1jp38cr"><div class="css-cw8msf eqi4ubu0"><div class="css-kzd6pg"><p><span class=css-97bxx6><a class="authorPageLinkClass overrideLinkStyles" href=https://www.nytimes.com/by/zachary-small>Zachary Small</a></span> is a reporter who covers the dynamics of power and privilege in the art world. In May she was awarded $100,000 by the ","formats":[]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Guggenheim Museum","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.guggenheim.org\u002Fvideo\u002Fartist-profile-stephanie-dinkins","title":""}]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":" for her groundbreaking innovations, including an ongoing series of interviews with Bina48, a humanoid robot.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":0,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"For the past seven years, she has experimented with A.I.’s ability to realistically depict Black women, smiling and crying, using a variety of word prompts. The first results were lackluster if not alarming: Her algorithm produced a pink-shaded humanoid shrouded by a black cloak.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":1,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"“I expected something with a little more semblance of Black womanhood,” she said. And although the technology has improved since her first experiments, Dinkins found herself using runaround terms in the text prompts to help the A.I. image generators achieve her desired image, “to give the machine a chance to give me what I wanted.” But whether she uses the term “African American woman” or “Black woman,” machine distortions that mangle facial features and hair textures occur at high rates.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":2,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"“Improvements obscure some of the deeper questions we should be asking about discrimination,” Dinkins said. The artist, who is Black, added, “The biases are embedded deep in these systems, so it becomes ingrained and automatic. If I’m working within a system that uses algorithmic ecosystems, then I want that system to know who Black people are in nuanced ways, so that we can feel better supported.”","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsDesktop":true,"index":3,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"She is not alone in asking tough questions about the troubling relationship between A.I. and race. Many Black artists are finding evidence of racial bias in artificial intelligence, both in the large data sets that teach machines how to generate images and in the underlying programs that run the algorithms. In some cases, A.I. technologies seem to ignore or distort artists’ text prompts, affecting how Black people are depicted in images, and in others, they seem to stereotype or censor Black history and culture.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":4,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Discussion of racial bias within artificial intelligence has surged in recent years, with studies showing that ","formats":[]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"facial recognition technologies","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2018\u002F02\u002F09\u002Ftechnology\u002Ffacial-recognition-race-artificial-intelligence.html","title":""}]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":" and digital assistants have trouble identifying the images and ","formats":[]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"speech","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F23\u002Ftechnology\u002Fspeech-recognition-bias-apple-amazon-google.html","title":""}]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":" patterns of nonwhite people. The studies raised broader questions of fairness and bias.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":5,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Major Dobson, a cultural historian at Dartmouth College and the author of a recent book on the ","formats":[]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"birth of computer vision","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.upress.umn.edu\u002Fbook-division\u002Fbooks\u002Fthe-birth-of-computer-vision","title":""}]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":". There was very little discussion about race during the early days of machine learning, according to his research, and most scientists working on the technology were white men.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":true,"index":26,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"“It’s hard to separate today’s algorithms from that history, because engineers are building on those prior versions,” Dobson said.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsDesktop":false,"index":27,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"To decrease the appearance of racial bias and hateful images, some companies have banned certain words from text prompts that users submit to generators, like “slave” and “fascist.”","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":28,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"But Dobson said that companies hoping for a simple solution, like censoring the kind of prompts that users can submit, were avoiding the more fundamental issues of bias in the underlying technology.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":29,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"“It’s a worrying time as these algorithms become more complicated. And when you see garbage coming out, you have to wonder what kind of garbage process is still sitting there inside the model,” the professor added.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":30,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Auriea Harvey","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fauriea.art\u002F","title":""}]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":", an artist included in the Whitney Museum’s recent ","formats":[]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"exhibition","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwhitney.org\u002Fexhibitions\u002Frefigured","title":""}]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":" “Refiguring,” about digital identities, bumped into these bans for a recent project using Midjourney. “I wanted to question the database on what it knew about slave ships,” she said. “I received a message saying that Midjourney would suspend my account if I continued.”","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsDesktop":false,"index":31,"bad":true},{"__typename":"ImageBlock","size":"MEDIUM","media":{"id":"SW1hZ2U6bnl0Oi8vaW1hZ2UvM2JmZmNiZmQtODlmZC01ZTgzLTlmYTktZDAwM2NiZmUzYmJh","imageType":"photo","url":"\u002Fimagepages\u002F2023\u002F07\u002F04\u002Fmultimedia\u002F03ai-bias10-qcjt.html","uri":"nyt:\u002F\u002Fimage\u002F3bffcbfd-89fd-5e83-9fa9-d003cbfe3bba","credit":"Flo Ngala for The New York Times","legacyHtmlCaption":"Stephanie Dinkins, inaugural recipient of the LG Guggenheim Award for technology-based art, in her studio in Brooklyn. A computer monitor and other devices are visible in the background.","__typename":"Image"}},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":true,"index":32,"bad":true},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Dinkins ran into similar problems with NFTs that she created and sold showing how okra was brought to North America by enslaved people and settlers. She was censored when she tried to use a generative program, ","formats":[]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Replicate","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Freplicate.com\u002F","title":""}]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":", to make pictures of slave ships. She eventually learned to outwit the censors by using the term “pirate ship.” The image she received was an approximation of what she wanted, but it also raised troubling questions for the artist.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":33,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"“What is this technology doing to history?” Dinkins asked. “You can see that someone is trying to correct for bias, yet at the same time that erases a piece of history. I find those erasures as dangerous as any bias, because we are just going to forget how we got here.”","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":34,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Naomi Beckwith, chief curator at the Guggenheim Museum, credited Dinkins’s nuanced approach to issues of representation and technology as one reason the artist received the museum’s first Art & Technology award.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsDesktop":false,"index":35,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"“Stephanie has become part of a tradition of artists and cultural workers that poke holes in these overarching and totalizing theories about how things work,” Beckwith said. The curator added that her own initial paranoia about A.I. programs replacing human creativity was greatly reduced when she realized these algorithms knew virtually nothing about Black culture.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":36,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"But Dinkins is not quite ready to give up on the technology. oembed.summary: Tech companies acknowledge machine-learning algorithms can perpetuate discrimination and need improvement.

readabilityObject.title: Black Artists Say A.I. Shows Bias, With Algorithms Erasing Their History
readabilityObject.content:
Advertisement

SKIP ADVERTISEMENT

Tech companies acknowledge machine-learning algorithms can perpetuate discrimination and need improvement.

The artist Stephanie Dinkins has long been a pioneer in combining art and technology in her Brooklyn-based practice. In May she was awarded $100,000 by the Guggenheim Museum for her groundbreaking innovations, including an ongoing series of interviews with Bina48, a humanoid robot.

For the past seven years, she has experimented with A.I.’s ability to realistically depict Black women, smiling and crying, using a variety of word prompts. The first results were lackluster if not alarming: Her algorithm produced a pink-shaded humanoid shrouded by a black cloak.

“I expected something with a little more semblance of Black womanhood,” she said. And although the technology has improved since her first experiments, Dinkins found herself using runaround terms in the text prompts to help the A.I. image generators achieve her desired image, “to give the machine a chance to give me what I wanted.” But whether she uses the term “African American woman” or “Black woman,” machine distortions that mangle facial features and hair textures occur at high rates.

“Improvements obscure some of the deeper questions we should be asking about discrimination,” Dinkins said. The artist, who is Black, added, “The biases are embedded deep in these systems, so it becomes ingrained and automatic. If I’m working within a system that uses algorithmic ecosystems, then I want that system to know who Black people are in nuanced ways, so that we can feel better supported.”

She is not alone in asking tough questions about the troubling relationship between A.I. and race. Many Black artists are finding evidence of racial bias in artificial intelligence, both in the large data sets that teach machines how to generate images and in the underlying programs that run the algorithms. In some cases, A.I. technologies seem to ignore or distort artists’ text prompts, affecting how Black people are depicted in images, and in others, they seem to stereotype or censor Black history and culture.

Discussion of racial bias within artificial intelligence has surged in recent years, with studies showing that facial recognition technologies and digital assistants have trouble identifying the images and speech patterns of nonwhite people. The studies raised broader questions of fairness and bias.

Major companies behind A.I. image generators — including OpenAI, Stability AI and Midjourney — have pledged to improve their tools. “Bias is an important, industrywide problem,” Alex Beck, a spokeswoman for OpenAI, said in an email interview, adding that the company is continuously trying “to improve performance, reduce bias and mitigate harmful outputs.” She declined to say how many employees were working on racial bias, or how much money the company had allocated toward the problem.

“Black people are accustomed to being unseen,” the Senegalese artist Linda Dounia Rebeiz wrote in an introduction to her exhibition “In/Visible,” for Feral File, an NFT marketplace. “When we are seen, we are accustomed to being misrepresented.”

To prove her point during an interview with a reporter, Rebeiz, 28, asked OpenAI’s image generator, DALL-E 2, to imagine buildings in her hometown, Dakar. The algorithm produced arid desert landscapes and ruined buildings that Rebeiz said were nothing like the coastal homes in the Senegalese capital.

“It’s demoralizing,” Rebeiz said. “The algorithm skews toward a cultural image of Africa that the West has created. It defaults to the worst stereotypes that already exist on the internet.”

Last year, OpenAI said it was establishing new techniques to diversify the images produced by DALL-E 2, so that the tool “generates images of people that more accurately reflect the diversity of the world’s population.”

An artist featured in Rebeiz’s exhibition, Minne Atairu is a Ph.D. candidate at Columbia University’s Teachers College who planned to use image generators with young students of color in the South Bronx. But she now worries “that might cause students to generate offensive images,” Atairu explained.

Included in the Feral File exhibition are images from her “Blonde Braids Studies,” which explore the limitations of Midjourney’s algorithm to produce images of Black women with natural blond hair. When the artist asked for an image of Black identical twins with blond hair, the program instead produced a sibling with lighter skin.

“That tells us where the algorithm is pooling images from,” Atairu said. “It’s not necessarily pulling from a corpus of Black people, but one geared toward white people.”

She said she worried that young Black children might attempt to generate images of themselves and see children whose skin was lightened. Atairu recalled some of her earlier experiments with Midjourney before recent updates improved its abilities. “It would generate images that were like blackface,” she said. “You would see a nose, but it wasn’t a human’s nose. It looked like a dog’s nose.”

In response to a request for comment, David Holz, Midjourney’s founder, said in an email, “If someone finds an issue with our systems, we ask them to please send us specific examples so we can investigate.”

Stability AI, which provides image generator services, said it planned on collaborating with the A.I. industry to improve bias evaluation techniques with a greater diversity of countries and cultures. Bias, the A.I. company said, is caused by “overrepresentation” in its general data sets, though it did not specify if overrepresentation of white people was the issue here.

Earlier this month, Bloomberg analyzed more than 5,000 images generated by Stability AI, and found that its program amplified stereotypes about race and gender, typically depicting people with lighter skin tones as holding high-paying jobs while subjects with darker skin tones were labeled “dishwasher” and “housekeeper.”

These problems have not stopped a frenzy of investments in the tech industry. A recent rosy report by the consulting firm McKinsey predicted that generative A.I. would add $4.4 trillion to the global economy annually. Last year, nearly 3,200 start-ups received $52.1 billion in funding, according to the GlobalData Deals Database.

Technology companies have struggled against charges of bias in portrayals of dark skin from the early days of color photography in the 1950s, when companies like Kodak used white models in their color development. Eight years ago, Google disabled its A.I. program’s ability to let people search for gorillas and monkeys through its Photos app because the algorithm was incorrectly sorting Black people into those categories. As recently as May of this year, the issue still had not been fixed. Two former employees who worked on the technology told The New York Times that Google had not trained the A.I. system with enough images of Black people.

Other experts who study artificial intelligence said that bias goes deeper than data sets, referring to the early development of this technology in the 1960s.

“The issue is more complicated than data bias,” said James E. Dobson, a cultural historian at Dartmouth College and the author of a recent book on the birth of computer vision. There was very little discussion about race during the early days of machine learning, according to his research, and most scientists working on the technology were white men.

“It’s hard to separate today’s algorithms from that history, because engineers are building on those prior versions,” Dobson said.

To decrease the appearance of racial bias and hateful images, some companies have banned certain words from text prompts that users submit to generators, like “slave” and “fascist.”

But Dobson said that companies hoping for a simple solution, like censoring the kind of prompts that users can submit, were avoiding the more fundamental issues of bias in the underlying technology.

“It’s a worrying time as these algorithms become more complicated. And when you see garbage coming out, you have to wonder what kind of garbage process is still sitting there inside the model,” the professor added.

Auriea Harvey, an artist included in the Whitney Museum’s recent exhibition “Refiguring,” about digital identities, bumped into these bans for a recent project using Midjourney. “I wanted to question the database on what it knew about slave ships,” she said. “I received a message saying that Midjourney would suspend my account if I continued.”

Dinkins ran into similar problems with NFTs that she created and sold showing how okra was brought to North America by enslaved people and settlers. She was censored when she tried to use a generative program, Replicate, to make pictures of slave ships. She eventually learned to outwit the censors by using the term “pirate ship.” The image she received was an approximation of what she wanted, but it also raised troubling questions for the artist.

“What is this technology doing to history?” Dinkins asked. “You can see that someone is trying to correct for bias, yet at the same time that erases a piece of history. I find those erasures as dangerous as any bias, because we are just going to forget how we got here.”

Naomi Beckwith, chief curator at the Guggenheim Museum, credited Dinkins’s nuanced approach to issues of representation and technology as one reason the artist received the museum’s first Art & Technology award.

“Stephanie has become part of a tradition of artists and cultural workers that poke holes in these overarching and totalizing theories about how things work,” Beckwith said. The curator added that her own initial paranoia about A.I. programs replacing human creativity was greatly reduced when she realized these algorithms knew virtually nothing about Black culture.

But Dinkins is not quite ready to give up on the technology. She continues to employ it for her artistic projects — with skepticism. “Once the system can generate a really high-fidelity image of a Black woman crying or smiling, can we rest?”

C

, Page

1

of the New York edition
